abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated satisfactory.
            However, the present uncertainty in Venezuela, which is
            described in greater detail in the report, makes it
            difficult to predict project sustainability in the medium
            term. Therefore, the more conservative unlikely rating is
            chosen to characterize project sustainability. The
            performances of both the World Bank and the Borrower are
            considered satisfactory overall. Lessons learned included
            the following:  1) The pace and sequencing of
            decentralization should be commensurate with the capacity of
            sector institutions at the central and local government
            levels: Political decentralization took place without fully
            considering the potential impact of decentralizing road
            management to the states. In this manner, the sequencing of
            road sector decentralization diverges with international
            best practice of first creating the appropriate institutions
            and the corresponding financing mechanisms at the central
            level and then setting up the local entities to carry out
            administrative, technical, and operational activities for
            road management. Contrary to its original intention, the
            government did not establish a road network for national
            interest in which the central government would retain some
            management responsibilities, nor did it define a plan to
            share responsibilities and resources with the states. The
            central government should have also retained greater control
            over coordination and planning for the national road network
            to ensure adequate integration and continuity of activities
            among the states. 2) The appropriate sector financing
            mechanisms need to be in place prior to political
            decentralization: Decentralization was carried out without
            the establishment of appropriate financing mechanisms for
            road maintenance activities. A road fund was designed under
            the project, but was not approved by the National Congress
            by project end. As a result, the lack of sustainable sector
            financing mechanisms has placed severe limits on resource
            availability, constraining the ability of state governments
            to manage and maintain their respective road networks. The
            lack of sustainable financing mechanisms has made
            decentralization more vulnerable to potential policy
            reversals, especially during periods of political and
            economic instability.  3) Project design needs to be
            appropriate for political, institutional, and legal
            realities: Project design was not appropriate given the
            limited experience of the GoV in implementing Bank projects
            in the sector as well as a number of uncertainties regarding
            the decentralization agenda at the time of appraisal.
            Moreover, project scope and size exceeded the absorptive
            capacities of the Borrower, leading to the cancellation of
            US$40.0 million of the original loan amount.  4) There is a
            need to develop adequate capacity and improve coordination
            in implementing simultaneous institutional strengthening
            programs at the national and state levels. 5) Maintaining
            continuity was an important factor in enabling the Bank to
            build relationships with the Borrower over the long-term.
            Throughout most of the project implementation period, the
            composition of the Bank supervision team remained relatively
            unchanged, with the same task manager during the entire life
            of the project, from signing to closing, despite a number of
            reorganizations within the Bank.  This allowed for the
            comprehensive identification of Borrower needs as well as
            the resolution of implementation difficulties.

abstracts.cdata!:
The Highways Management Project's
            primary objectives are to: (a) rehabilitate and maintain the
            national paved highway network; and (b) establish
            sustainable institutional mechanisms to ensure effective
            road maintenance in the future within a framework of a
            decentralized road administration. The project will consist
            of: (1) a policy and institutional development program,
            including technical assistance and training of staff; (2) an
            investment program consisting of the highest-priority
            highway and bridge rehabilitation and resurfacing components
            of the Transport Ministry and the General Directorate of
            Road's program; and (3) a maintenance program
            consisting of routine and periodic maintenance works, which
            will be fully funded with local resources.
